bestBHT.bht: Jesus approached a fig tree that had leaves but no fruit, even though it was not yet the season for figs. This was unusual, as the leaves on a fig tree typically appear after the fruit. Perhaps the tree was prematurely and unnaturally developed, giving the appearance of promise without performance. Jesus, hungry from the previous day's events, hoped to find fruit on the tree, but it was barren. This event serves as a parable, symbolizing the pretentious hypocrisy of the Jewish hierarchy, and a reproof of the unfruitfulness of the Jewish Church.

Henry Alford: The tree was precocious, in being clothed with leaves.
If it had bad on it winter figs, which remain on from the autumn, and ripen early the next season, they would have been ripe at this time.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Afar off having leaves—and therefore promising fruit, which in the case of figs come before the leaves.
He came, if haply he might find any thing thereon: and when he came to it, he found nothing but leaves for the time of figs was not yet.

Perhaps all that is meant is, that as the proper fig season had not arrived, no fruit would have been expected even of this tree but for the leaves which it had, which were in this case prematurely and unnaturally developed.
Marvin Vincent: Having leaves. An unusual thing at that early season.
If, such being the case, i e., the tree having leaves - he might find fruit, which, in the fig, precedes the leaf.
Mark alone adds, 'for the time of figs was not yet.'
Philip Schaff: Mark presents the appearance of the tree in the distance: having leaves.
This scarcely implies doubt in His mind, since the design was to teach the Apostles a very important lesson.
The failure was then in the barrenness of the tree, a fit symbol of the pretentious hypocrisy of the Jewish hierarchy.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus was hungry as if he had had no food on the night before after the excitement and strain of the Triumphal Entry.
The early figs in Palestine do not get ripe before May or June, the later crop in August.
John Gill: And when he came to it, he found nothing but leaves; no fruit at all upon it, contrary to his expectation as man, and the promising appearance the tree made."

Either because the time of gathering figs was not come; and since therefore they were not gathered, he might the rather hope to find some on it; or because it was not a kind season for figs, a good fig year; and this tree appearing in such a flourishing condition, might raise his expectation of finding fruit, yet he found none but leaves only.

Because it was so bad a season for figs, that even the most promising trees had none upon them: or this, tree being of an uncommon sort, though Christ expected to find no fruit on other trees, because the time of common: figs was not come, yet he might hope to, find some on this.
John Wesley: It was not a good year for figs.
It may be considered as the reason of Christ's going to see whether there were any figs on this tree.
The great design of the parable, which was to reprove the Jewish Church for its unfruitfulness at that very season, when fruit might best be expected from them.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus approached a fig tree that had leaves but no fruit, even though it was not yet the season for figs. This was unusual, as the leaves on a fig tree typically appear after the fruit. Perhaps the tree was prematurely and unnaturally developed, giving the appearance of promise without performance. Jesus, hungry from the previous day's events, hoped to find fruit on the tree, but it was barren. This event serves as a parable, symbolizing the pretentious hypocrisy of the Jewish hierarchy, and a reproof of the unfruitfulness of the Jewish Church.

Approaching a fig tree that had leaves but no fruit, Jesus found nothing but leaves, as it was not yet the time for figs. This apparent promise without performance was unusual, given that figs usually appear before the leaves. Hoping for fruit, Jesus was disappointed by the barren tree. This event symbolizes the hypocrisy of the Jewish hierarchy and serves as a rebuke to the unfruitfulness of the Jewish Church, highlighting the need for genuine faith and righteousness.

Approaching the fig tree, Jesus was disappointed to find that it had leaves but no fruit, even though it was not yet the time for figs. This barren tree, with its promise without performance, was an unusual sight, as figs usually appear before the leaves. Jesus, hungry from the previous day's events, had hoped to find fruit on the tree. This event served as a parable, symbolizing the hypocrisy of the Jewish hierarchy and rebuking the unfruitfulness of the Jewish Church.

Approaching the tree covered with leaves, Jesus found no fruit, for it was not yet the time for figs. The tree's barrenness, despite its promising appearance, was unusual and disappointing. Jesus, hungry from the prior day, had hoped to find fruit. This event served as a parable, exposing the hypocrisy of the Jewish hierarchy and rebuking the unfruitfulness of the Jewish Church. It revealed the need for genuine faith and righteousness, emphasizing the importance of producing spiritual fruit.

Approaching the fig tree, Jesus found nothing but leaves, as it was not yet the time for figs. The tree's barrenness, with its promise without performance, disappointed Him. This event exposed the hypocrisy of the Jewish hierarchy and served as a rebuke to the unfruitfulness of the Jewish Church. In this parable, Jesus highlighted the need for genuine faith and righteousness, emphasizing the importance of producing spiritual fruit. It symbolized the urgent call for the people to reflect their professed faith through meaningful actions.
